Habits Are Seldom Changed in Later Life.--What the child sees and hears is drawing deep lines upon the tender mind, which no after circumstances in life can 


                                                 151 

entirely efface. The intellect is now taking shape and the affections receiving direction and strength. Repeated acts in a given course become habits. These may be modified by severe training, in afterlife, but are seldom changed.--GH, Jan, 1880. (CG 199, 200.)
